qas.question: When did the French try to create co-masonic lodges?
When did the United Grand Lodge of England recognize the two female Masonic lodges?
What did the french lodges promote to try to get women accepted into the Freemasons?

answers.text: the 33rd degree of the Ancient and Accepted Scottish Rite

qas.question: Do Anglo-American grand lodges accept women as members today?

answers.text: most regular Anglo-American grand lodges remains that women Freemasons are not legitimate Masons

qas.question: When did Russia try to create co-masonic lodges?
When did the United Grand Lodge of England forget the two female Masonic lodges?

plausible_answers.text: the 33rd degree of the Ancient and Accepted Scottish Rite

qas.question: What did the french lodges promote to try to get men accepted into the Freemasons?
Where are women recognized as the ideal Masons?

context: In general, Continental Freemasonry is sympathetic to Freemasonry amongst women, dating from <a0_0><b4_0>the 1890s<b4_0/><a0_0/> when French lodges assisted the emergent co-masonic movement by promoting enough of their members to <a2_0><b6_0>the 33rd degree of the Ancient and Accepted Scottish Rite<b6_0/><a2_0/> to allow them, in 1899, to form their own grand council, recognised by the other Continental Grand Councils of that Rite. The United Grand Lodge of England issued a statement in <a1_0><b5_0>1999<b5_0/><a1_0/> recognising the two women's grand lodges there to be regular in all but the participants. While they were not, therefore, recognised as regular, they were part of Freemasonry "in general". The attitude of <a3_0><b7_0>most regular Anglo-American grand lodges<b7_0/> remains that women Freemasons are not legitimate Masons<a3_0/>.
